Booker sparks 2nd-half surge as UK tops BU

Freshman shooting guard has career-high 15 points and seven assists.

Booker sparks 2nd-half surge as UK tops BU

Video | Devin Booker on UK's win over BU

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 11:47 p.m. EST November 21, 2014

Kentucky guard Dominique Hawkins, right, makes a basket in the first half. The University of Kentucky Men's Basketball team hosted Boston University, Friday, Nov. 21, 2014 at Rupp Arena in Lexington. Photo by Jonathan Palmer, Special to the CJ(Photo: Jonathan Palmer / Special to The Courier-Journal)

17 CONNECT 13 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Quick, somebody conduct a poll: Can the Boston University basketball team play with the Philadelphia 76ers for a half? The Terriers gave top-ranked Kentucky all it wanted for a little longer than that before falling 89-65 Friday night at Rupp Arena, just three days after the Wildcats throttled fifth-ranked Kansas by 32.

Talk of an undefeated season and that nagging hypothetical about college basketball's best against the NBA's worst were fueled by how thoroughly UK (4-0) thumped a perennial power, but BU brought the hype back down a notch for the night. Despite the final margin, the visitors were within a bucket in the second half.

"Coming off the Kansas game, that was such a high-energy game, and I think the younger guys, the adrenaline wasn't flowing like it was," said sophomore guard Aaron Harrison, who had a team-high 19 points. "We just have to learn to be physical, because every team is gonna try to be physical with us, of course."

RELATED: Game Rewind | UK pulls away late from Boston

RELATED: Instant Analysis | Kentucky-Boston University

The Cats kept threatening to blow it open in the first half, twice leading by 10, but the Terriers kept closing the gap, hitting six 3-pointers, forcing eight Kentucky turnovers and trailing just 40-35 at the break. John Calipari scrapped his two-platoon system early in the second half and needed an unlikely hero to pull away.

"I expected a letdown," the Cats' coach said. "I was just hoping it wouldn't be too bad."

Freshman shooting guard Devin Booker who hit just 25 percent of his shots, including 1 of 11 3-pointers, and averaged only five points in his first three games came to the rescue with a red-hot second half. He finished with new career highs of 15 points and seven assists, hitting 5 of 8 shots, including 4 of 6 threes.

He really shined, though, when the Wildcats needed it most. Boston's Cedric Hankerson, who finished with 24 points, drained one of his five 3-pointers to slash Kentucky's lead to 46-44 with 16:18 to go, which signaled the end of Calipari's mass substitutions. He mixed and matched the rest of the way.

Booker was a constant as the Cats blew the game open. In the span of four and a half minutes, he swished three 3-pointers, nailed a pull-up jumper, threw a pair of lobs to fellow freshman Trey Lyles and dished to junior Willie Cauley-Stein for another dunk to balloon the lead to 18 points with seven minutes to go.

"Finally got to see a shot go in," Booker said. "It was real relieving. Shooters keep shooting. That's what people keep telling me, so I shot myself out of it, and I feel like from here on out I'll be good."

Sophomore guard Dominique Hawkins a surprise starter in place of Alex Poythress, who was out with an illness punctuated the furious finish with a skying slam off Booker's last lob. The 6-foot-tall Hawkins brought the crowd to its feet with his feat.

He was a sparkplug in the first half, running with the first platoon. He swiped a steal and swished a pull-up jumper, drained a 3-pointer, out-jumped a guy five inches taller for a rebound, forced an airball and dove to tie up the Terriers on a loose ball. At one point, he so smothered his man, the offensive player's knees buckled.

"It was crazy," Hawkins said of his first career start. "I was so nervous about it. I was just focusing on not messing up at the beginning of the game."

    Hawkins, a former Kentucky Mr. Basketball who hadn't scored for UK this season, finished with seven points. Another Mr. Baskteball, BU's Nathan Dieudonne, had 10 points, five rebounds and four assists before fouling out in his return to Rupp, where he led Trinity High to the 2012 state championship.

    Six Wildcats finished with at least eight points, including Harrison's big night. He had a highlight-reel play of his own in the first half, driving baseline, leaping up and under the basket and dropping in a reverse scoop shot.

    Kentucky also got 12 points from Cauley-Stein and 11 from sophomore center Dakari Johnson, who also had six rebounds. The starters with Hawkins fared far better than the Cats' second platoon Friday, outscoring BU 24-15. The second wave was outscored 20-16.

    That platoon was pulled after just 67 seconds and three straight turnovers in the first half and yanked again just 62 seconds into the second half. Soon after, the platoon system was history for the remainder of the game.

    "We all expect this team to be world-beaters every night out, and let me say, folks, they're not going to be," Calipari said, "and there are games I'm going to have to drag them across the finish line."

    Kyle Tucker can be reached at (502) 582-4361. Follow him on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ.

    Kentucky basketball coach John Calipari talks about UK's tougher-than-expected win over Boston University.
